B0.desc: Understand container security fundamentals: how containers work, shared responsibility, and common risks.
B0.relevance: Container isolation concepts, image vs runtime distinction, core orchestration primitives, common threat patterns (privilege escalation, vulnerable base images).

B1.desc: Recognize default OpenShift platform security layers that protect workloads by default.
B1.relevance: Immutable OS / control plane hardening layers, managed lifecycle updates, builtâ€‘in default security posture.

B2.desc: Grasp basic access control: users, groups, and simple RBAC role bindings.
B2.relevance: RBAC roles/rolebindings, OAuth authentication, basic service account usage.

B3.desc: Understand default workload guardrails limiting container permissions and resources.
B3.relevance: Default workload permission boundaries, pod security policy tiers, resource quota and limit range concepts.

B4.desc: Explain basic in-cluster network isolation using NetworkPolicies.
B4.relevance: Network segmentation policies (allow/deny patterns), namespace isolation, baseline ingress/egress concepts.

B5.desc: Know how Secrets store sensitive values and basic protection expectations.

B6.desc: Identify trusted image sources and perform basic vulnerability scanning awareness.
B6.relevance: Trusted image source curation, base image hygiene, introductory image vulnerability awareness.

B7.desc: Understand the purpose of audit and cluster logs for accountability.
B7.relevance: Control plane / workload audit events, centralized log aggregation patterns, forwarding to monitoring / analytics platforms.

B8.desc: Be aware of built-in security extension operators (what they do, not how to configure).
B8.relevance: Security extension capabilities: compliance scanning, workload profile enforcement, runtime security visibility (high-level only).

B9.desc: Explain least privilege for workloads: non-root, minimal capabilities, limited namespaces.
B9.relevance: Non-root containers, minimal privileges via SCC/PSA defaults, capability minimization.

B10.desc: Understand basic encryption protections for data in transit and at rest.
B10.relevance: Transport encryption fundamentals, termination patterns, basic at-rest encryption concepts.

I1.desc: Apply practical threat modeling to applications and workloads deployed on OpenShift.
I1.relevance: Data flow mapping, attack surface review using access, security, and network controls context, policy insight interpretation.

I2.desc: Implement advanced RBAC and service account security including token hardening.
I2.relevance: Fine-grained roles, aggregated roles, service account scoping, bound service account tokens, least privilege patterns.

I3.desc: Customize and enforce workload security controls to prevent privilege escalation.
I3.relevance: Custom SCCs, Pod Security Admission configuration, SELinux types, seccomp profiles (usage).

I4.desc: Design network segmentation and implement egress/ingress controls across namespaces.
I4.relevance: Advanced segmentation policies, egress governance patterns, multi-network attachment concepts, perimeter / firewall integration.

I5.desc: Integrate security scanning and policy checks into CI/CD pipelines.
I5.relevance: Pipeline-integrated scanning gates, policy-as-code engines, build-time compliance and configuration checks.

I6.desc: Manage secret lifecycle: rotation, external encryption, and controlled distribution.
I6.relevance: Secret rotation workflows, external key management integration, encrypted distribution abstractions.

I7.desc: Correlate audit logs and monitoring signals to detect suspicious activity.
I7.relevance: Audit log parsing, centralized log querying patterns, runtime telemetry correlation for anomaly detection.

I8.desc: Automate compliance assessments and remediation workflows.
I8.relevance: Compliance scan tailoring, security benchmark execution, compliance dashboard interpretation, automated remediation scripting.

I9.desc: Apply advanced workload restriction profiles for tighter isolation.
I9.relevance: Custom workload restriction profiles (seccomp, MAC policies), syscall minimization strategies.

I10.desc: Govern resource and security posture with admission and policy controllers.
I10.relevance: Admission / policy controller constraints, aggregated policy set management, custom admission extension patterns.

I11.desc: Build secure, minimal, and reproducible container images with basic signing & attestation integration.
I11.relevance: Dockerfile/Build strategy hardening (least packages, non-root, multi-stage), reproducible builds, embedding metadata (labels/SBOM), basic artifact signing and attestation generation/verification in the development workflow.

A1.desc: Lead platform-wide security governance and multi-team architecture decisions.
A1.relevance: Security operating model, RBAC & namespace strategy, segmentation blueprints.

A2.desc: Implement GitOps-driven policy and compliance pipelines at scale.
A2.relevance: GitOps reconciliation, policy-as-code repositories, automated drift detection.

A3.desc: Architect multi-tenant zero-trust network and service segmentation.
A3.relevance: Service mesh mTLS, layered NetworkPolicies, multi-network CNIs, egress governance, zero-trust patterns.

A4.desc: Engineer runtime threat detection pipelines and integrate them into response workflows.
A4.relevance: Runtime detection rulesets, streaming telemetry enrichment, alert routing design, pre-incident response playbooks.

A5.desc: Lead coordinated incident response and forensic investigation on the platform.
A5.relevance: Forensic data collection, timeline reconstruction, threat intel correlation, root cause analysis.

A6.desc: Establish end-to-end supply chain integrity and artifact provenance.
A6.relevance: Artifact signing frameworks, SBOM generation & attestation, supply chain assurance levels, supply chain policy enforcement.

A7.desc: Automate remediation and policy enforcement using controllers and operators.
A7.relevance: Custom controller/operator patterns, policy mutation strategies, automated remediation actions.

A8.desc: Drive security culture, coaching teams and maturing practices.
A8.relevance: Enablement programs, documentation standards, internal guilds, maturity roadmaps.

A9.desc: Design advanced cryptography, observability, and encryption strategies.
A9.relevance: Key management integration, service-to-service encryption architecture, observability and audit telemetry pipeline design.

A10.desc: Implement zero-trust workload identity and confidential computing.
A10.relevance: Workload identity frameworks, confidential execution runtimes, hardware-backed attestation mechanisms.

responsibilities.R9: Harden OpenShift nodes and perform patch management using OpenShift tooling.
responsibilities.R10: Integrate OpenShift audit logs with monitoring and Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) systems.

responsibilities.R12: Automate compliance checks with Compliance Operator aligned to industry security standards.
responsibilities.R13: Embed security controls and best practices in CI/CD pipelines, collaborating closely with development teams.
responsibilities.R14: Provide training and documentation on OpenShift platform security and best practices.
responsibilities.R15: Design secure, scalable OpenShift architectures integrating compliance and monitoring capabilities.
responsibilities.R16: Lead governance and policy definition aligned with organizational security standards and Zero Trust principles.
responsibilities.R17: Automate vulnerability assessments and remediation workflows within OpenShift environments.
responsibilities.R18: Mentor teams on secure design, security best practices, and continuous security improvement.
responsibilities.R19: Create and manage secure, automated OpenShift deployment pipelines incorporating SAST, DAST, and vulnerability scanning.
responsibilities.R20: Manage infrastructure as code (IaC) securely, including container builds and deployment.
responsibilities.R21: Enforce security policies through admission controllers such as Gatekeeper integrated with OpenShift.

responsibilities.R23: Implement encryption for data in transit and at rest within and outside OpenShift clusters.
responsibilities.R24: Monitor and manage network traffic for anomalies and mitigate Denial of Service (DoS) attacks.

responsibilities.R26: Implement Zero Trust security models for workloads and manage workload isolation effectively.
responsibilities.R27: Manage OpenShift security infrastructure including Identity and Access Management (IAM), SIEM, EDR, and policy enforcement.
responsibilities.R28: Maintain and update security policies and documentation, ensuring operational security and compliance.
responsibilities.R29: Coordinate with Product Lifecycle Management to align security initiatives with product goals.
responsibilities.R30: Define and manage ResourceQuotas and LimitRanges per project to prevent resource exhaustion and enforce platform guardrails.
responsibilities.R31: Maintain artifact signing and attestation verification gates across build and deployment workflows.
responsibilities.R32: Define and automate secret lifecycle processes including rotation, revocation, and external secret backend integration.
responsibilities.R33: Engineer and tune runtime detection rules and telemetry pipelines for actionable alerts.
responsibilities.R34: Orchestrate multi-cluster security and compliance policy propagation and consistency.
responsibilities.R35: Govern temporary security control exceptions with approval, tracking, and expiry enforcement.
responsibilities.R36: Implement and govern workload identity issuance and trust policies (identity-based authorization).
responsibilities.R37: Produce secure, minimal, reproducible container images and apply basic signing/attestation in the build workflow.
responsibilities.R41: Engineer secure service-to-service trust fabric (mesh policy layering, identity-based routing, egress/ingress governance).

Application Developer.description: Build secure containerized applications focusing on fundamentals, trusted images, secrets, and integrating baseline security into delivery.

Platform Operator.description: Operate and harden clusters: enforce policies, manage access, logging, compliance, quotas, and platform security posture.

DevSecOps Engineer.description: Embed security in pipelines, enforce policy gates, manage supply chain and runtime feedback loops.

Security Architect.description: Design platform security architecture, governance models, segmentation, compliance, and zero-trust strategy.

Network & Infrastructure Engineer.description: Specialized ownership of data plane security: advanced segmentation, secure service-to-service trust, encryption patterns, identity-aware routing, and traffic anomaly engineering.
